content: President Obama signed the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) into law on March 23, 2010, which includes provisions affecting Medicare payments and benefits. The Health Care and Education Affordability Reconciliation Act of 2010 (HCERA) was signed into law on March 30, 2010, making changes to Medicare-related provisions in PPACA. The Medicare and Medicaid Extenders Act of 2010, signed on December 15, 2010, also modified certain PPACA provisions related to Medicare. The PPACA includes provisions affecting Medicare payments and benefits. CBO estimates show net reductions in Medicare direct spending reaching close to $400 billion over the FY2010-FY2019 period. The legislation includes various program modifications, payment method reforms, and program integrity changes to address fraud, waste, and abuse in Medicare. The Reconciliation Act includes provisions related to health care, revenues, and amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965. It modifies Medicare fee-for-service, Medicare Advantage, and Medicare outpatient prescription drug programs, as well as addresses reducing waste, fraud, and abuse in Medicare. The Extenders Act contains provisions that extend or modify certain Medicare-related provisions in PPACA and the Reconciliation Act. It discusses the financial impact on Medicare, changes by provider type and program, efforts to address efficiencies and quality, long-term financing, and program integrity changes. Appendix A provides an overview of Medicare-related provisions in the laws. The Reconciliation Act and the Extenders Act include provisions related to Medicare, with details on timelines for payment updates and effective dates. The Congressional Budget Office and Joint Committee on Taxation issued cost estimates for the PPACA as amended by the Reconciliation Act. CBO estimates that provisions in PPACA and the Reconciliation Act will reduce direct spending by $511 billion over FY2010-FY2019, with Medicare accounting for $400 billion of the reduction. Total Medicare reductions in direct spending over 10 years are estimated at $465 billion, offset by payment increases of close to $65 billion. Medicare-related provisions in the Extenders Act are estimated to cost an additional $1.9 billion through FY2020. Key savings provisions include permanent reductions in fee-for-service payment rates, tying Medicare Advantage payment rates to fee-for-service levels, reducing payments to DSH hospitals, and modifying high-income adjustments for Part B premiums, totaling $378.3 billion in estimated savings over 10 years. The health care reform legislation includes various cost-saving measures such as adjustments for Part B premiums, an Independent Payment Advisory Board, new taxes on high-income individuals, and investment income. These measures are projected to save billions over 10 years and slow down the growth of Medicare spending compared to previous years. However, there is uncertainty in the estimates, particularly regarding the sustainable growth rate mechanism for Medicare physician payment rates. Physician payment rates were set to go back into effect in 2010, with a projected 21% cut in payments. The Independent Payment Advisory Board established by PPACA aims to reduce costs, but it is unclear if this will be achieved through greater efficiencies or if it will impact the quality of care. Medicare covers health services for individuals 65 and older, as well as disabled individuals under 65, with different parts responsible for various benefits and financing mechanisms. Traditional Medicare pays for services on a fee-for-service basis. Medicare payment rates are set annually by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) using different payment systems. MedPAC makes payment update recommendations to Congress in March each year, examining Medicare payments' adequacy for efficient providers and assessing likely provider cost changes. Medicare's payment systems aim to encourage efficiency gains similar to the economy at large, linking expectations for efficiency improvements to productivity gains achieved by firms and workers funding Medicare. MedPAC's update recommendations for Medicare payment rates depend on provider circumstances. Part A covers inpatient hospital services, skilled nursing, home health, and hospice care for beneficiaries. Approximately 20% of Part A enrollees use these services annually. Prior to PPACA, Part A spending was projected to increase significantly. Provisions in the PPACA and Reconciliation Act will reduce Part A spending by constraining payment updates to hospitals, restructuring payments for treatment inefficiencies, and reshaping DSH hospital subsidies. Additionally, the exception allowing physician-owned hospitals to refer Medicare and Medicaid patients will be eliminated for new hospitals or those not meeting criteria. Medicare's annual payment updates to Part A hospitals will be adjusted for productivity increases, leading to significant cost savings. The PPACA provision will adjust payment updates for Part A hospitals using a 10-year moving average of productivity gains, leading to significant Medicare spending reductions. This includes savings for outpatient and inpatient services for all hospitals, with potential additional savings for acute care hospitals serving low-income patients. The PPACA provision will reduce hospitals' DSH payments starting in FY2014 by 25%, based on MedPAC's recommendations. Additional payments to acute care hospitals will be determined by factors such as changes in the uninsured population and the amount of uncompensated care provided. This policy is estimated to save $22.1 billion from FY2015 onwards. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 required the establishment of a prospective payment system for skilled nursing facilities (SNFs) to cover all services provided, including room and board, nursing, therapy, and drugs. SNFs receive a daily payment based on 1995 costs adjusted for inflation, with profits retained by the SNF and losses absorbed by the SNF. The daily base payment varies by urban or rural location and is further adjusted for area wages using the hospital wage index. The daily payments for skilled nursing facilities (SNFs) are adjusted for variations in area wages using the hospital wage index. SNF per diem payments are also adjusted for HIV-positive or AIDS residents. Medicare payments to SNFs were found to be adequate in a 2009 report, recommending the elimination of the market basket update for 2010. The market basket update for FY2010 was 2.2 percentage points, and a revised case-mix classification methodology (RUG-IV) was established for FY2011. The FY2010 final rule revised the case-mix classification methodology (RUG-IV) and implementation schedule for FY2011. Changes were made to correct for budget neutrality estimates exceeding payments for medically complex patients. The rule also addressed billing therapy concurrently in SNFs, requiring them to adjust how they bill for therapy given to Medicare patients. The FY2010 final rule required SNFs to report individual therapy minutes on the MDS 3.0 for billing purposes. Changes were made to billing for high-cost staff-intensive services. The RUG billing system no longer includes costs of certain services as a proxy for medical complexity due to poor analysis results. Medicare Advantage (MA) is a payment model where private health plans receive a set amount to cover all Medicare benefits for enrollees. Plans bid for the amount they will charge, with rebates given if the bid is below the benchmark. If the bid is above the benchmark, the plan must charge a premium. Rebates must be used for additional benefits. Congress historically increases benchmark amounts through specified formulas. The benchmark amounts for Medicare Advantage plans have historically been increased by Congress to encourage plan participation nationwide. The benchmarks currently range from 100% to over 150% of fee-for-service Medicare costs. The Affordable Care Act changed how maximum payments to MA plans are determined, phasing in benchmarks based on FFS Medicare spending percentages. This change will lead to reductions in many benchmarks, but also increases benchmarks in certain counties. PPACA increases benchmarks based on plan quality, with higher increases for qualifying quality plans in qualifying areas. Plans with at least a 4-star rating on a 5-star quality rating scale will receive an increase in their benchmark. New plans or plans with low enrollment may also qualify for a benchmark increase. PPACA also varies plan rebates based on quality, with new rebates set at 50% to 70% of the difference between the plan bid and the benchmark. Additionally, PPACA requires a coding intensity adjustment to plan payments after 2010 to account for the cost of providing care. The Deficit Reduction Act of 2005 required adjustments for coding differences between MA plans and providers under Medicare. PPACA mandates further analysis and coding adjustments post-2010, with estimated savings of $135.6 billion over FY2010-FY2019. This will lead to a 35% decrease in MA enrollment by 2019, with average subsidies for extra benefits decreasing to $67 per month. They suggest that Medicare's fee-for-service system rewards excessive care and lacks service coordination. It also establishes a Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation to develop cost-saving care delivery models. Medicare's financial operations are managed through two trust funds. The Hospital Insurance (HI) trust fund and the Supplementary Medical Insurance (SMI) trust fund, maintained by the Department of the Treasury, finance Medicare. The HI trust fund is funded by payroll taxes, projected to become insolvent in 2017. If this happens, Congress would need to decide how to continue funding Medicare Part A. Additionally, PPACA will impose an additional 0.9% tax. PPACA will save $15.5 billion between 2015 and 2019. It imposes an additional tax on high-income workers and unearned income. The Medicare Boards of Trustees predict that lower Part A costs and higher tax revenues will postpone the depletion of HI trust fund assets until 2029. The CBO and CMS Office of the Actuary warn against combining trust fund accounting with budget rules. Medicare expenditure reductions can extend HI trust fund solvency or offset health insurance expansion costs, but double-counting savings should be avoided. Health care fraud costs billions annually, with estimates ranging from 3% to 10% of expenditures. As health care costs rise, new approaches to combat fraud are crucial. CMS works to prevent, detect, and fight fraud in Medicare and private insurance programs. CMS conducts program integrity activities to prevent, detect, and investigate health care fraud, sharing responsibility with OIG, DOJ, and FBI. OIG detects fraud in federal health care programs, FBI investigates fraud in both private and public programs, and suspected cases are referred to DOJ for prosecution. Anti-fraud provisions in PPACA and the Reconciliation Act target program integrity activities, enforcement efforts, and funding for anti-fraud activities.
